THE ACADEMIC POINT OF VIEW.
Practical men object to what they call "the
academic point of view," and object with so
much emphasis and persistency that there
must be something more than a mere ignorant dislike at the bottom of their feeling in
the matter. Indeed, I think that academic
men once and again catch themselves entertaining the same feeling for a brief interval, if
they stir much abroad in the world. An uneasy consciousness creeps in upon them that
their ordinary way of looking at things in the
lecture hall and in class-room discussions is a
very much specialized way and seems always
a little narrow and impractical when used in
the midst of affairs. It may be, in its place, a
necessary and useful way of looking at things,
and better suited than most to clarified reasoning ; but it involves standing at a peculiar
point of view, hardly practicable for men outside the University; and, though we may
Choose to retain it, it is best that we should
understand just what it is and know how, by
keeping it, we differ from the man of affairs.
If a man of affairs were asked what it was
that made him feel out of sympathy with university teachers and with the pupils who had
been most recently under their influence, he
would probably say that practical men look at
things as they are, but that university men prefer to look at things as they ought to be; and
that, since things are not as they ought to be,
university men usually fail to get practicable
opinions, for all their thinking. Some of this
the university man must admit. He studies
facts to get at principles, and when he has arrived at his principles he perceives that some
of the facts he has recorded and examined are
essential, while the rest are subsidiary and in
a sense accidental — aside from the point.
These latter he forthwith puts on one side and
proceeds to neglect, and builds his reasoning
on the significant
and essential matters which
he has sifted out.
He has reached his "aca-

No. 5

demic point of view," and has set his reasoning free from encumbrance. He has discovered how things would be if principles operated
singly, simply, without mixture or confusion
of irrelevant things. However concrete his
.facts, they are selected facts, and he is reasoning in the abstract, looking at the gross world
in analysis, and not in combination.
That is why the practical man regards him
with uneasiness and charges him with dealing
in unrealities. The practical man knows that
in affairs things cannot be treated as simples :
facts cannot be selected. Logically irrelevant
circumstances may in actual life have as much
importance as circumstances which are of the
essence of the business in hand, and, however
much you may wish to sift the pertinent from
the impertinent, you cannot do it. They are,
in fact, inseparable, and you must deal with
them in the bulk, not according to their quality, but according to their gross weight and
quantity. You are apt to be rendered incapable of dealing with actual life, the practical man
believes, by dealing so much with your own
abstract and partial analysis of it. You may
have a perfectly developed logical faculty, and
yet no practical sagacity whatever : your practice in abstract reasoning may even tend to destroy your native sense of what is wise and
practicable, for it may render you impatient
with makeshift and management, your only
means of success. The new-fledged college
graduate always wants to "turn the world upside down," older men complain, and that very
desire proves his unwise training.
There is something in these objections that
college men ought to heed. We should not
give up abstract reasoning or stop subjecting
facts to a careful differentiation and sifting.
We must continue to separate facts and to
classify them, to purge away their accidental
elements, and to come at their secrets of abstract principle and intrinsic law. We could
have no science, otherwise, and no adequate
knowledge of the world in its elements; and

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

unless'we knew it in its elements we could not
know it in its action as a whole, complex and
fruitful of power. But we should have the
other side of knowledge, too — that feeling for
affairs which is synthetic and which shall enable us to deal with rough life as we find it.
We must not fall out of sympathy with life because it is not like what we make of it in our
laboratories and in our seminaries. We must
be proper men of the world, as well as trained
academic reasoners must know when and
where "the academic point of view" is to be
taken and when and where it is entirely out of
place, and pedantic.
No doubt the best way to reach this balance
and readiness at adjustment is to give our
minds a various diet and a liberal view of the
world, by reading books that are full of the
common life of the world, as well as books
upon our own special topics of academic
study — the better sort of novels, with real
people in them, such as masters like Fielding
and Sienkiewicz can create; such poetry as
runs hot with the motives that send men to action and to self-sacrifice; such histories as contain the real rush and variety of life; and travels that meant something more for the traveler
than mere sight-seeing or mere pleasure. University men seldom have time during their
term of study for real contact with affairs; but
they can put their minds every day for a little
while into the air of the world that moves outside laboratories and lecture halls, in streets
and markets, on prairie and ocean, on frontiers
and battle-fields, in households and in the lobbies of parliaments — and so not forget that
other side of things which the practical man
fears he may forget. He should not for a moment despise his "academic point of view"
(for the advancement of exact knowledge and,
in the end, the progress of the world depend
upon its assiduous cultivation) ; but he should
be ready to abandon it, and should instinctively
abandon it, the moment it becomes unsuitable
for the practical business of life. He must not
be a pedant : he must be a trained thinker who
is also a man of the world.
WOODROW WILSON.

DR. VINCENT ON "GENEVA."
Professor Vincent delivered a very entertaining address upon "Geneva" before the
Historical and Political Science Association
on Friday evening. His talk was based upon
personal reminiscences of his visit to the city
last summer. The worthy professor was considerably shocked at the rather loose observance of the Sabbath. Every Sunday morning
he was awakened by target practice under his
window ; and, after enjoying a very pious sermon, was accustomed to see the worthy
preacher regaling himself with a game of ten
pins and other kindred amusements. Elections are always held on that day; and in consideration of municipal politics, it is worthy to
note that the Genevese do not apparently care
for the luxury of a mayor, and consequently
entrust the duties of that office to a council.
The Church and State are very closely connected, ministers being elected by popular vote
of the people, and have their salaries paid by
the Government. The laboring classes are
poor, but not subdued; and nowhere in Europe, says Professor Vincent, did he find that
characteristically American broadness of
views and democratic instincts so prevalent as
in Geneva. The beauties of the place are seldom exaggerated. The effect of the gorgeous
grandeur of its surrounding rivers and mountains make a picture almost too glorious for
description.
In accordance with Professor Adams' custom of making the library and lecture-rooms
as attractive as possible, quite a number of new
pictures and paintings have been added to the
large number which now hang upon the walls.
"Boswell," said Dr. Johnson, meeting the
biographer on the street, "I have been reading some of your manuscripts. There is a
great deal about yourself in them. They seem
to me to be Youmoirs rather than Memoirs."—
Puck.
Professor: How dare you swear before me?
Freshman: How did I know you wanted to
swear first.—Exchange.

THE MUSICAL ASSOCIATION.
It is proposed to form a musical association
at the Johns Hopkins University. Only persons enrolled in the register of the University
and their wives are eligible to membership.
The annual dues will be $1. The association
will give four evening musicales, under the direction of Mr. W.Edward Heimendahl, in McCoy Hall, during the months of December,
January, February and March. The number
of persons present at the musicales is limited
to 250. Membership tickets may be obtained at the office of the Registrar of the University. The arrangements are made by the
following persons:
President and Mrs. Gilman,
Prof. P. Haupt,
Mrs. E. H. Griffin,
Mrs. M.Bloomfield, Dr.T.S. Baker,
Dr. Philip Ogden,
Mrs. Paul Haupt,
Mrs. H.E. Greene,
Mr. C. C. Schenck,
Mrs. William Bullock Clark.
The first meeting of the association will be
held on Friday, December 17, at 8:15 P. M.,
with the following programme:
I. Joseph Haydn (1732-1809):
String quartet in D major.
(a) Allegro moderato.
(b) Adagio cantabile.
(c) Menuetto : Allegretto.
(d) Finale: Vivace.
Messrs. Heimendahl, Moses, Saunders,
Furth meyer.
2. Franz Liszt (1811-1886):
(a) Etude in D fiat major.
(b) Liebestraum Nocturne.
Miss Hermine Liiders.
3. Max Bruch (1838):
Violin concerto in G minor.
Second movement: Adagio.
Mr. W. Edward Heimendahl.
4. Robert Schumann (1810-1856):
Dichterliebe.
Five songs : Nos. I, 2, 3, 4 and 7.
Mr. T. S. Baker.
5. Anton Rubinstein (1830-1894):
Piano concerto in D minor.
First movement :
Miss Hermine Luders.

"PREPARATION FOR PUBLIC LIFE."
The joint session of the Congress on November 8 was held for the purpose of listening
to an address by President Gilman. Speaker
French, of the House, called the meeting to
order, and after welcoming the Senate to the
joint session, gave up the chair to President
Dieffenbach, of the Senate. The Censor announced that the President desired to address
the meeting, and Messrs. Straus and Grimes
were appointed to escort him to the room.
In his speech Dr. Gilman dwelt upon the
value of presence to a speaker, and advised the
members of the Congress, when speaking, to
talk to the most remote of his audience, and
to catch their attention individually. He also
brought forward the obligation which lies
upon every young man to take active interest
in public affairs, and pointed out the many
chances open to them to enter the public service. Dr. Gilman was suffering from a severe
cold and made his address only by great effort. He was listened to with great interest,
and heartily applauded. Messrs. Fitzgerald
and Knapp were appointed to escort him to
his office. The meeting then adjourned.
THE CUBAN QUESTION.
Each meeting of the Senate is an improvement on the previous one. Last Wednesday
the presence of President Gilman and Dean
Griffin lent a dignity to the session, which did
not result in stage fright among the speakers,
but, on the contrary, seemed to inspire them to
debate more forcibly and fluently. Indeed, so
well was the subject handled that Senator Ballard, when called upon in the open debate,
found he could add nothing to what had already been said, which was somewhat surprising. The subject was: "Should the United
States intervene in behalf of Cuba?" Senators
Clarke, Seth and Fender made good arguments for Cuba, and Senators Stearns and
Hammond defended the negative side of the
question. Senator Ulman was absent. Senator Clarke's speech was the feature of the de(Continued on Page 8.)

The new Musical Association which is being started for members of the University and
for their wives promises to be very successful
and to occupy a much-needed place in the University. There is an unusual number of music
lovers and musicians at the University, but
they have never before been gathered into
any organization. The Association, besides
encouraging music at the University, will, to
a great degree, serve as a social organization.
Refreshments will be served after each meeting, and the members of the University will be
given an opportunity to become better acquainted. The dues of the Association are
only nominal and the membership, which is
limited in number to 250, will be composed of
members of the University and their wives.

PROFESSORS PATTON AND SCHrlIDT.

The authorities of the University are fortunate enough to be able to announce that Professor Erich Schmidt, of the University of
Berlin, has consented to deliver the Percy
Turnbull memorial lectures in the session of
1898-99. The lectures will be given in German, and the subject will be "Goethe." Professor Schmidt is one of the most distinguished scholars in Germany, and as a lecturer he is said to be quite as remarkable as M.
Brunetiere, who gave the last course of Turnbull lectures.
President Patton, of Princeton University,
has accepted an invitation to deliver the Levering lectures for the current year. The lectures
will be three in number and will be given about
the first of February. The subject will be announced later.

The party consisted of Morris L. Barr, the

NEWS NOTES.

Candidates for the Glee Club are being tried
this week at the Alpha Delta Phi Fraternity
house. Only a few of the new candidates have
been taken so far, but nearly all the members
of last year's club are trying again this year.
The Banjo and Mandolin Clubs have begun
regular practice ; the latter club is larger than
ever before, while nearly all the members of
the Banjo Club having played together for
three years, it is expected that that organization will be better this year than since the
splendid club of '94-95. J. G. Peters, '98, is
again leader of both clubs.
A meeting of the class of 1900 was held
Wednesday, December 1. The awards of the
offices of class historian, poet and artist were
made. Herbert Kaufman was successful for
the offices of historian and artist, and Edward
P. Hyde for poet. The offices were awarded
by competition. Roland T. Abercrombie was
elected delegate to the new Athletic Association.

ATHLETICS.
BASEBALL

Captain Clarke, in an interview, has the following to say on 'varsity baseball:
Now that the football season is nearly over,
Hopkins men are beginning to ask what are
our prospects of having a good baseball team.
What chance have we of winning the championship of the State? In previous years this
question has invariably been asked and has as
often received the answer : "Fine," only to
be made ridiculous later on by a long string of
defeats. Therefore, with these experiences in
mind, we prefer to waive a direct answer to
your question, and trust that time and the
course of events will give you ample compensation for your waiting.
Although we are not predicting success, we
are, nevertheless, not without strong hopes
that, by hard work and consistent training, we
may bring the 1898 championship to adorn the
walls of our new gymnasium. This brings up
the question : Will the baseball team really
train ? If so, what method will be pursued?
We answer : Yes, they must train.
Why
shouldn't they ? Other college teams feel the
necessity of training, and Hopkins men,
surely, can't afford to neglect it. This statement hardly needs further explanation, for all
of us know that a team, no matter how good
its players may be individually, cannot hope to
compete successfully with its opponents, unless it has acquired that perfection of team
play which comes only by hard and constant
practice.
Let no man imagine that the team has already been "picked," for positively no "sifting" of material will take place before we
shall have had outdoor practice. Let every
student who plays ball hand in his name to
Manager Haulenbeek, for even if he shouldn't
"make the 'Varsity," he may "make the
scrub" which will be organized to give the
first team at least one practice game a week.
Several promising candidates have already
appeared, among whom are: Haulenbeek,
Wight, Joyner, Hitzrot, Rogers, Foster,

Fletcher, Wirt, Rickey, Grimes, Talty, Everett, Swaine, Warren and others. Now that
we are to have our cage, and consequently
can arrange an hour and place suitable to the
Medical men for practice, we expect to get out
some of the fine material always to be found
at the Medical School.
But the success of any team depends on the
encouragement and support given it by the
students, and, realizing this, we ask only for
an honest trial before condemnation.
ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION.

The Athletic Association held its first meeting yesterday afternoon in Hopkins Hall. Officers were elected as follows:
President—Professor Edward A. Renouf.
Vice-President—Wm. H. Maddren (Medical School).
Secretary—Frank J. Clunet ('98).
Treasurer—Dr. J. Bascom Crenshaw.
The other delegates are : Robert Garrett,
G. Canby Robinson and George W.Knapp,Jr.
A 'Varsity handball team,consisting of Wm.
H. Maddren and Ward Simmons, was recognized by the Athletic Association. During the
holidays these men will represent Hopkins in
a contest with the Polytechnic team of Brooklyn. It is Hopkins' first move in this sport,
and the start is a very auspicious one.
The proposed formation of a new lacrosse
association by Harvard, Yale, Pennsylvania
and Cornell, in the face of a strongly organized
association in existence at present, was also
settled. The Hopkins will prevent this by
joining the Inter-collegiate Athletic Association, thereby completing, with Lehigh and
Stevens, a deal for full and official recognition
as the only lacrosse association.
It was decided that a house committee
would have charge of the new gymnasium
when completed. One graduate, two seniors,
one junior and one freshman will compose the
committee, with the consent of the faculty.
HOCKEY.

The Hockey League is at present in a state
of uncertainty. At the last meeting of the
Board of Delegates a dispute arose in regard

THE NEWS-LETTER.
to the admission of the Maryland Hockey
Team into the League, and the percentage of
gate receipts to be allowed the team. All the
teams represented voted against admitting the
Marylands, and against lowering the percentage from ten to five per cent. Manager Towers, of the rink, took the other side, however,
and the meeting ended in a disagreement.
Until there is a mutual agreement between the
rink management and the various teams and
players, there will hardly be any city championship games. The rink is making arrangements for outside teams to play the Maryland
Hockey Team,but, as these teams are brought
on at a great expense in most instances, there
will be very little profit by such action. Unless there are well-contested local games, it is
almost safe to say that there will be very little
interest taken in visiting teams.
It is hoped that an early solution to the
problem will be brought forward and amicable relations cemented among the contending
parties.
LACROSSE.

A dispatch from Cambridge, stating that the
manager of the Harvard lacrosse team has
opened negotiations with the lacrosse authorities at Yale, Columbia, Cornell and the University of Pennsylvania, informs us of the revival of lacrosse among the Northern colleges.
Two years ago Harvard played Hopkins to
a tie. There was a time when Cornell and
Princeton had first-class tennis, but during the
past few years little or no interest has been
taken in lacrosse at these institutions.
It would be of great advantage to all if these
colleges, which contemplate reviving lacrosse, would apply for membership to the
Inter-Collegiate Lacrosse Association, which
is composed of Hopkins, Lehigh and Stevens.
Ample provision is to be made in the new
cage for the track team. Next the walls a cinder track is to be laid out, and banked at all the
curves. It will be an eighteen-lap track. Here
the team can train at all times and in all weath-

7

ers. Dr. Shattuck, assistant in geology, has
offered to coach the men, and Mr. MacDermott will probably be with us as well.
The records recently made by Robert Garrett under J. H. U. colors in outdoor broad
jump and throwing the discus and indoor 16pound-shot-put have been adopted by the
Maryland Board of Records.

President Gilman, in a two-minute talk recommended that the members attend a session
of the National Congress in Washington to
gain points in parliamentary practice and debating. He also congratulated the Senators
upon their work, and promised to have a clock
on the wall of the Senate Chamber in time for
the next meeting.
Senator Bestor read several reports from
other colleges where forensic oratory has been
tried. Their tone, on the whole, was not encouraging. The Congress at Johns Hopkins
is now a successful reality. It has been suggested that the reason of this is that the conduct of the Congress is happily in charge of
faculty and students. In this respect it differs
from the ordinary course, and gives the advantages of a debating society, combined with the
valued advice of an experienced instructor.
The subject for debate for the next session
is : "Resolved, That capital punishment be
abolished." Senators Dohme, C. Hodges and
Hubner, affirmative, and Senators Robinson,
F. W. Smith and Gordon, negative.
The fourth regular meeting of the House of
Representatives was held Wednesday, November 24. The debate, "Resolved, That the
United States should intervene in the case of
Cuba," was very spirited, and showed careful
preparation on the part of the debaters. That
the debaters spoke with hardly any reference
to their notes was very gratifying, and added
much to the interest of the debate. The negative side, which consisted of Congressmen
Guggenheimer, Ross and Fischer, won the debate. The Censor, in his criticism, complimented the negative side on their earnest work
in preparation for the dabate. Congressman
Fischer, he said, was very witty and effective
in his arguments. The affirmative side was
somewhat handicapped by the absence of one
of their regular debaters. Congressman Lev-

ering was asked to fill the vacancy. The subject for debate at the next regular meeting of
the House will be : "Resolved, That capital
punishment should be abolished." The debaters will be : Affirmative — Congressmen
Remsen, Keidel and Welber. Negative—Congressmen Murkland, Davidson and Krager.
The House was favored with the presence of
Dr. Greene and Dr. Vincent.

Dr. L. F. Barke held his first quiz in histology on Friday, December 3, which will be followed by one on each succeeding Friday
throughout the course. These quizzes are so
original and interesting that the students look
forward to them with more pleasure than fear.
The quizzes in anatomy will be conducted this
year by Drs. Mall, Lord and Harrison.
It is to be hoped that the smoker which the
first-year class had prepared to have some
weeks ago, has not been permanently postponed. By this informal means the studeatt
would meet and know each other, which, otherwise, may not be accomplished for some
time, owing to the unusual size of the class.
Arrangements for smokers should be made
as soon as possible, for before long everyone
will be so busy that the interest for its success
will be subordinate.

THE ACADEMIC POINT OF VIEW.
Practical men object to what they call "the
academic point of view," and object with so
much emphasis and persistency that there
must be something more than a mere ignorant dislike at the bottom of their feeling in
the matter. Indeed, I think that academic
men once and again catch themselves entertaining the same feeling for a brief interval, if
they stir much abroad in the world. An uneasy consciousness creeps in upon them that
their ordinary way of looking at things in the
lecture hall and in class-room discussions is a
very much specialized way and seems always
a little narrow and impractical when used in
the midst of affairs. It may be, in its place, a
necessary and useful way of looking at things,
and better suited than most to clarified reasoning ; but it involves standing at a peculiar
point of view, hardly practicable for men outside the University; and, though we may
Choose to retain it, it is best that we should
understand just what it is and know how, by
keeping it, we differ from the man of affairs.
If a man of affairs were asked what it was
that made him feel out of sympathy with university teachers and with the pupils who had
been most recently under their influence, he
would probably say that practical men look at
things as they are, but that university men prefer to look at things as they ought to be; and
that, since things are not as they ought to be,
university men usually fail to get practicable
opinions, for all their thinking. Some of this
the university man must admit. He studies
facts to get at principles, and when he has arrived at his principles he perceives that some
of the facts he has recorded and examined are
essential, while the rest are subsidiary and in
a sense accidental — aside from the point.
These latter he forthwith puts on one side and
proceeds to neglect, and builds his reasoning
on the significant
and essential matters which
he has sifted out.
He has reached his "aca-

No. 5

demic point of view," and has set his reasoning free from encumbrance. He has discovered how things would be if principles operated
singly, simply, without mixture or confusion
of irrelevant things. However concrete his
.facts, they are selected facts, and he is reasoning in the abstract, looking at the gross world
in analysis, and not in combination.
That is why the practical man regards him
with uneasiness and charges him with dealing
in unrealities. The practical man knows that
in affairs things cannot be treated as simples :
facts cannot be selected. Logically irrelevant
circumstances may in actual life have as much
importance as circumstances which are of the
essence of the business in hand, and, however
much you may wish to sift the pertinent from
the impertinent, you cannot do it. They are,
in fact, inseparable, and you must deal with
them in the bulk, not according to their quality, but according to their gross weight and
quantity. You are apt to be rendered incapable of dealing with actual life, the practical man
believes, by dealing so much with your own
abstract and partial analysis of it. You may
have a perfectly developed logical faculty, and
yet no practical sagacity whatever : your practice in abstract reasoning may even tend to destroy your native sense of what is wise and
practicable, for it may render you impatient
with makeshift and management, your only
means of success. The new-fledged college
graduate always wants to "turn the world upside down," older men complain, and that very
desire proves his unwise training.
There is something in these objections that
college men ought to heed. We should not
give up abstract reasoning or stop subjecting
facts to a careful differentiation and sifting.
We must continue to separate facts and to
classify them, to purge away their accidental
elements, and to come at their secrets of abstract principle and intrinsic law. We could
have no science, otherwise, and no adequate
knowledge of the world in its elements; and

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

unless'we knew it in its elements we could not
know it in its action as a whole, complex and
fruitful of power. But we should have the
other side of knowledge, too — that feeling for
affairs which is synthetic and which shall enable us to deal with rough life as we find it.
We must not fall out of sympathy with life because it is not like what we make of it in our
laboratories and in our seminaries. We must
be proper men of the world, as well as trained
academic reasoners must know when and
where "the academic point of view" is to be
taken and when and where it is entirely out of
place, and pedantic.
No doubt the best way to reach this balance
and readiness at adjustment is to give our
minds a various diet and a liberal view of the
world, by reading books that are full of the
common life of the world, as well as books
upon our own special topics of academic
study — the better sort of novels, with real
people in them, such as masters like Fielding
and Sienkiewicz can create; such poetry as
runs hot with the motives that send men to action and to self-sacrifice; such histories as contain the real rush and variety of life; and travels that meant something more for the traveler
than mere sight-seeing or mere pleasure. University men seldom have time during their
term of study for real contact with affairs; but
they can put their minds every day for a little
while into the air of the world that moves outside laboratories and lecture halls, in streets
and markets, on prairie and ocean, on frontiers
and battle-fields, in households and in the lobbies of parliaments — and so not forget that
other side of things which the practical man
fears he may forget. He should not for a moment despise his "academic point of view"
(for the advancement of exact knowledge and,
in the end, the progress of the world depend
upon its assiduous cultivation) ; but he should
be ready to abandon it, and should instinctively
abandon it, the moment it becomes unsuitable
for the practical business of life. He must not
be a pedant : he must be a trained thinker who
is also a man of the world.
WOODROW WILSON.

DR. VINCENT ON "GENEVA."
Professor Vincent delivered a very entertaining address upon "Geneva" before the
Historical and Political Science Association
on Friday evening. His talk was based upon
personal reminiscences of his visit to the city
last summer. The worthy professor was considerably shocked at the rather loose observance of the Sabbath. Every Sunday morning
he was awakened by target practice under his
window ; and, after enjoying a very pious sermon, was accustomed to see the worthy
preacher regaling himself with a game of ten
pins and other kindred amusements. Elections are always held on that day; and in consideration of municipal politics, it is worthy to
note that the Genevese do not apparently care
for the luxury of a mayor, and consequently
entrust the duties of that office to a council.
The Church and State are very closely connected, ministers being elected by popular vote
of the people, and have their salaries paid by
the Government. The laboring classes are
poor, but not subdued; and nowhere in Europe, says Professor Vincent, did he find that
characteristically American broadness of
views and democratic instincts so prevalent as
in Geneva. The beauties of the place are seldom exaggerated. The effect of the gorgeous
grandeur of its surrounding rivers and mountains make a picture almost too glorious for
description.
In accordance with Professor Adams' custom of making the library and lecture-rooms
as attractive as possible, quite a number of new
pictures and paintings have been added to the
large number which now hang upon the walls.
"Boswell," said Dr. Johnson, meeting the
biographer on the street, "I have been reading some of your manuscripts. There is a
great deal about yourself in them. They seem

THE MUSICAL ASSOCIATION.
It is proposed to form a musical association
at the Johns Hopkins University. Only persons enrolled in the register of the University
and their wives are eligible to membership.
The annual dues will be $1. The association
will give four evening musicales, under the direction of Mr. W.Edward Heimendahl, in McCoy Hall, during the months of December,
January, February and March. The number
of persons present at the musicales is limited
to 250. Membership tickets may be obtained at the office of the Registrar of the University. The arrangements are made by the
following persons:
President and Mrs. Gilman,
Prof. P. Haupt,
Mrs. E. H. Griffin,
Mrs. M.Bloomfield, Dr.T.S. Baker,
Dr. Philip Ogden,
Mrs. Paul Haupt,
Mrs. H.E. Greene,
Mr. C. C. Schenck,
Mrs. William Bullock Clark.
The first meeting of the association will be
held on Friday, December 17, at 8:15 P. M.,
with the following programme:
I. Joseph Haydn (1732-1809):
String quartet in D major.
(a) Allegro moderato.
(b) Adagio cantabile.
(c) Menuetto : Allegretto.
(d) Finale: Vivace.
Messrs. Heimendahl, Moses, Saunders,
Furth meyer.
2. Franz Liszt (1811-1886):
(a) Etude in D fiat major.
(b) Liebestraum Nocturne.
Miss Hermine Liiders.
3. Max Bruch (1838):
Violin concerto in G minor.
Second movement: Adagio.
Mr. W. Edward Heimendahl.
4. Robert Schumann (1810-1856):
Dichterliebe.
Five songs : Nos. I, 2, 3, 4 and 7.
Mr. T. S. Baker.
5. Anton Rubinstein (1830-1894):
Piano concerto in D minor.
First movement :
Miss Hermine Luders.

"PREPARATION FOR PUBLIC LIFE."
The joint session of the Congress on November 8 was held for the purpose of listening
to an address by President Gilman. Speaker
French, of the House, called the meeting to
order, and after welcoming the Senate to the
joint session, gave up the chair to President
Dieffenbach, of the Senate. The Censor announced that the President desired to address
the meeting, and Messrs. Straus and Grimes
were appointed to escort him to the room.
In his speech Dr. Gilman dwelt upon the
value of presence to a speaker, and advised the
members of the Congress, when speaking, to
talk to the most remote of his audience, and
to catch their attention individually. He also
brought forward the obligation which lies
upon every young man to take active interest
in public affairs, and pointed out the many
chances open to them to enter the public service. Dr. Gilman was suffering from a severe
cold and made his address only by great effort. He was listened to with great interest,
and heartily applauded. Messrs. Fitzgerald
and Knapp were appointed to escort him to
his office. The meeting then adjourned.
THE CUBAN QUESTION.
Each meeting of the Senate is an improvement on the previous one. Last Wednesday
the presence of President Gilman and Dean
Griffin lent a dignity to the session, which did
not result in stage fright among the speakers,
but, on the contrary, seemed to inspire them to
debate more forcibly and fluently. Indeed, so
well was the subject handled that Senator Ballard, when called upon in the open debate,
found he could add nothing to what had already been said, which was somewhat surprising. The subject was: "Should the United
States intervene in behalf of Cuba?" Senators
Clarke, Seth and Fender made good arguments for Cuba, and Senators Stearns and
Hammond defended the negative side of the
question. Senator Ulman was absent. Senator Clarke's speech was the feature of the de(Continued on Page 8.)

The new Musical Association which is being started for members of the University and
for their wives promises to be very successful
and to occupy a much-needed place in the University. There is an unusual number of music
lovers and musicians at the University, but
they have never before been gathered into
any organization. The Association, besides
encouraging music at the University, will, to
a great degree, serve as a social organization.
Refreshments will be served after each meeting, and the members of the University will be
given an opportunity to become better acquainted. The dues of the Association are
only nominal and the membership, which is
limited in number to 250, will be composed of
members of the University and their wives.

PROFESSORS PATTON AND SCHrlIDT.

The authorities of the University are fortunate enough to be able to announce that Professor Erich Schmidt, of the University of
Berlin, has consented to deliver the Percy
Turnbull memorial lectures in the session of
1898-99. The lectures will be given in German, and the subject will be "Goethe." Professor Schmidt is one of the most distinguished scholars in Germany, and as a lecturer he is said to be quite as remarkable as M.
Brunetiere, who gave the last course of Turnbull lectures.
President Patton, of Princeton University,
has accepted an invitation to deliver the Levering lectures for the current year. The lectures
will be three in number and will be given about
the first of February. The subject will be announced later.

NEWS NOTES.

Candidates for the Glee Club are being tried
this week at the Alpha Delta Phi Fraternity
house. Only a few of the new candidates have
been taken so far, but nearly all the members
of last year's club are trying again this year.
The Banjo and Mandolin Clubs have begun
regular practice ; the latter club is larger than
ever before, while nearly all the members of
the Banjo Club having played together for
three years, it is expected that that organization will be better this year than since the
splendid club of '94-95. J. G. Peters, '98, is
again leader of both clubs.
A meeting of the class of 1900 was held
Wednesday, December 1. The awards of the
offices of class historian, poet and artist were
made. Herbert Kaufman was successful for
the offices of historian and artist, and Edward
P. Hyde for poet. The offices were awarded
by competition. Roland T. Abercrombie was
elected delegate to the new Athletic Association.

ATHLETICS.
BASEBALL

Captain Clarke, in an interview, has the following to say on 'varsity baseball:
Now that the football season is nearly over,
Hopkins men are beginning to ask what are
our prospects of having a good baseball team.
What chance have we of winning the championship of the State? In previous years this
question has invariably been asked and has as
often received the answer : "Fine," only to
be made ridiculous later on by a long string of
defeats. Therefore, with these experiences in
mind, we prefer to waive a direct answer to
your question, and trust that time and the
course of events will give you ample compensation for your waiting.
Although we are not predicting success, we
are, nevertheless, not without strong hopes
that, by hard work and consistent training, we
may bring the 1898 championship to adorn the
walls of our new gymnasium. This brings up
the question : Will the baseball team really
train ? If so, what method will be pursued?
We answer : Yes, they must train.
Why
shouldn't they ? Other college teams feel the
necessity of training, and Hopkins men,
surely, can't afford to neglect it. This statement hardly needs further explanation, for all
of us know that a team, no matter how good
its players may be individually, cannot hope to
compete successfully with its opponents, unless it has acquired that perfection of team
play which comes only by hard and constant
practice.
Let no man imagine that the team has already been "picked," for positively no "sifting" of material will take place before we
shall have had outdoor practice. Let every
student who plays ball hand in his name to
Manager Haulenbeek, for even if he shouldn't
"make the 'Varsity," he may "make the
scrub" which will be organized to give the
first team at least one practice game a week.
Several promising candidates have already
appeared, among whom are: Haulenbeek,
Wight, Joyner, Hitzrot, Rogers, Foster,

Fletcher, Wirt, Rickey, Grimes, Talty, Everett, Swaine, Warren and others. Now that
we are to have our cage, and consequently
can arrange an hour and place suitable to the
Medical men for practice, we expect to get out
some of the fine material always to be found
at the Medical School.
But the success of any team depends on the
encouragement and support given it by the
students, and, realizing this, we ask only for
an honest trial before condemnation.
ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION.

The Athletic Association held its first meeting yesterday afternoon in Hopkins Hall. Officers were elected as follows:
President—Professor Edward A. Renouf.
Vice-President—Wm. H. Maddren (Medical School).
Secretary—Frank J. Clunet ('98).
Treasurer—Dr. J. Bascom Crenshaw.
The other delegates are : Robert Garrett,
G. Canby Robinson and George W.Knapp,Jr.
A 'Varsity handball team,consisting of Wm.
H. Maddren and Ward Simmons, was recognized by the Athletic Association. During the
holidays these men will represent Hopkins in
a contest with the Polytechnic team of Brooklyn. It is Hopkins' first move in this sport,
and the start is a very auspicious one.
The proposed formation of a new lacrosse
association by Harvard, Yale, Pennsylvania
and Cornell, in the face of a strongly organized
association in existence at present, was also
settled. The Hopkins will prevent this by
joining the Inter-collegiate Athletic Association, thereby completing, with Lehigh and
Stevens, a deal for full and official recognition
as the only lacrosse association.
It was decided that a house committee
would have charge of the new gymnasium
when completed. One graduate, two seniors,
one junior and one freshman will compose the
committee, with the consent of the faculty.
HOCKEY.

The Hockey League is at present in a state
of uncertainty. At the last meeting of the
Board of Delegates a dispute arose in regard

THE NEWS-LETTER.
to the admission of the Maryland Hockey
Team into the League, and the percentage of
gate receipts to be allowed the team. All the
teams represented voted against admitting the
Marylands, and against lowering the percentage from ten to five per cent. Manager Towers, of the rink, took the other side, however,
and the meeting ended in a disagreement.
Until there is a mutual agreement between the
rink management and the various teams and
players, there will hardly be any city championship games. The rink is making arrangements for outside teams to play the Maryland
Hockey Team,but, as these teams are brought
on at a great expense in most instances, there
will be very little profit by such action. Unless there are well-contested local games, it is
almost safe to say that there will be very little
interest taken in visiting teams.
It is hoped that an early solution to the
problem will be brought forward and amicable relations cemented among the contending
parties.
LACROSSE.

A dispatch from Cambridge, stating that the
manager of the Harvard lacrosse team has
opened negotiations with the lacrosse authorities at Yale, Columbia, Cornell and the University of Pennsylvania, informs us of the revival of lacrosse among the Northern colleges.
Two years ago Harvard played Hopkins to
a tie. There was a time when Cornell and
Princeton had first-class tennis, but during the
past few years little or no interest has been
taken in lacrosse at these institutions.
It would be of great advantage to all if these
colleges, which contemplate reviving lacrosse, would apply for membership to the
Inter-Collegiate Lacrosse Association, which
is composed of Hopkins, Lehigh and Stevens.
Ample provision is to be made in the new
cage for the track team. Next the walls a cinder track is to be laid out, and banked at all the
curves. It will be an eighteen-lap track. Here
the team can train at all times and in all weath-

7

ers. Dr. Shattuck, assistant in geology, has
offered to coach the men, and Mr. MacDermott will probably be with us as well.
The records recently made by Robert Garrett under J. H. U. colors in outdoor broad
jump and throwing the discus and indoor 16pound-shot-put have been adopted by the
Maryland Board of Records.

the open debate Senators R. D. Miller and

President Gilman, in a two-minute talk recommended that the members attend a session
of the National Congress in Washington to
gain points in parliamentary practice and debating. He also congratulated the Senators
upon their work, and promised to have a clock
on the wall of the Senate Chamber in time for
the next meeting.
Senator Bestor read several reports from
other colleges where forensic oratory has been
tried. Their tone, on the whole, was not encouraging. The Congress at Johns Hopkins
is now a successful reality. It has been suggested that the reason of this is that the conduct of the Congress is happily in charge of
faculty and students. In this respect it differs
from the ordinary course, and gives the advantages of a debating society, combined with the
valued advice of an experienced instructor.
The subject for debate for the next session
is : "Resolved, That capital punishment be
abolished." Senators Dohme, C. Hodges and
Hubner, affirmative, and Senators Robinson,
F. W. Smith and Gordon, negative.
The fourth regular meeting of the House of
Representatives was held Wednesday, November 24. The debate, "Resolved, That the
United States should intervene in the case of
Cuba," was very spirited, and showed careful
preparation on the part of the debaters. That
the debaters spoke with hardly any reference
to their notes was very gratifying, and added
much to the interest of the debate. The negative side, which consisted of Congressmen
Guggenheimer, Ross and Fischer, won the debate. The Censor, in his criticism, complimented the negative side on their earnest work
in preparation for the dabate. Congressman
Fischer, he said, was very witty and effective
in his arguments. The affirmative side was
somewhat handicapped by the absence of one
of their regular debaters. Congressman Lev-

ering was asked to fill the vacancy. The subject for debate at the next regular meeting of
the House will be : "Resolved, That capital
punishment should be abolished." The debaters will be : Affirmative — Congressmen
Remsen, Keidel and Welber. Negative—Congressmen Murkland, Davidson and Krager.
The House was favored with the presence of
Dr. Greene and Dr. Vincent.
11EDICAL SCHOOL NEWS.

Dr. L. F. Barke held his first quiz in histology on Friday, December 3, which will be followed by one on each succeeding Friday
throughout the course. These quizzes are so
original and interesting that the students look
forward to them with more pleasure than fear.
The quizzes in anatomy will be conducted this
year by Drs. Mall, Lord and Harrison.
It is to be hoped that the smoker which the
first-year class had prepared to have some
weeks ago, has not been permanently postponed. By this informal means the studeatt
would meet and know each other, which, otherwise, may not be accomplished for some
time, owing to the unusual size of the class.
Arrangements for smokers should be made
as soon as possible, for before long everyone
will be so busy that the interest for its success
will be subordinate.
CLASS rIEETINOS.

The class of '98 met on Wednesday and
elected Messrs. Clunet and F. W.Smith members of the Board of Directors of the Athletic
Association. President Fitzgerald also announced the executive committee, which consists of the President, ex-officio, and Messrs.
Seth, Clunet, Dieffenbach, Hodges, Harwood
and Scholl.
The class of i9oo met on Wednesday to
discuss class pins. They also voted an appropriation of $2o for representation in The Hullabaloo.
